hero.heading: Orchestrate, deploy, and manage containers, binaries, and batch jobs in the cloud or on-prem

overview.heading: What is Nomad?
overview.body: A simple and flexible scheduler and orchestrator to deploy and manage containers and non-containerized applications across on-prem and clouds at scale

get_started.heading: Getting Started
get_started.body: Learn how to use Nomad to schedule and orchestrate workloads.

cards.heading: Nomad sandbox
cards.body: The Nomad sandbox contains preinstalled tools and services for you to experiment with Nomad.

cards.heading: Create and Deploy Jobs
cards.body: Learn the fundamentals of expressing your workload as Nomad jobs.

cards.heading: Parameterized Jobs
cards.body: Nomad parameterized jobs enable dynamic runtime behaviors from a single job specification.

cards.heading: Nomad Pack
cards.body: Create and re-use existing job templates with Nomad Pack.

cards.heading: Integrate Consul
cards.body: Learn to secure jobs and add Consul health checking, service discovery, and service mesh capabilities.

cards.heading: Integrate Vault
cards.body: Configure the Nomad secrets engine in Vault and use Vault to obtain secrets for workloads.

cards.heading: Nomad Enterprise
cards.body: Learn about Nomad Enterprise features and how to use them at scale.

cards.heading: Secure Nomad with Access Control
cards.body: Learn to configure a Nomad cluster for ACLs, author your first policy, and grant a token based on it.

cards.heading: Enable Traffic Encryption for Nomad
cards.body: Encrypt Nomad's intercluster trafficâ€”UDP gossip and TCP API/RPC traffic.

cards.heading: Job Resiliency
cards.body: Learn to keep jobs running in the event of the unexpected with local retries and node rescheduling.

cards.heading: Governance and Policy
cards.body: Operate Nomad securely in a multi-team environment with resource quotas and Sentinel integration.

cards.heading: Advanced Application Scheduling
cards.body: Learn to express placement preferences for job allocations using affinities and preemption.

cards.heading: Build Nomad Clusters
cards.body: Learn the features operators need to build and maintain Nomad clusters.

cards.heading: Upgrade a Cluster
cards.body: Nomad is designed to be flexible and resilient when upgrading from one Nomad version to the next.

cards.heading: Task Drivers
cards.body: Task drivers are used by Nomad clients to execute a task and provide resource isolation. Extending task drivers allows Nomad the flexibility to support a broad set of workloads.

cards.heading: External Tools
cards.body: External tools provide additional capabilities and use cases to Nomad and can sometimes be deployed as a Nomad job in your cluster.

cards.heading: Define your container orchestrator
cards.body: Using infrastructure as code to define your container orchestration creates consistent, version-controlled specifications for Nomad.

cards.heading: Monitor your container orchestrator
cards.body: Monitoring container orchestrators is important for keeping your clusters and services healthy, and lets you sustain high performance and reliability.

cards.heading: Optimize your container orchestrator
cards.body: Container orchestrators allow your applications to scale quickly and enable you to optimize resource utilization.

cards.heading: Secure your container orchestrator
cards.body: A zero trust security model enhances security by eliminating implicit trust and continuously verifying access requests.

cards.heading: Create immutable containers
cards.body: Immutable containers package your application into an unchangeable unit that you build once and deploy one or more times.

cards.heading: Package applications
cards.body: Application packaging creates deployable artifacts that ensure consistency across environments and simplify deployment processes.

cards.heading: Centralize packages
cards.body: Centralize software artifacts and dependencies to streamline the build process and enhance security and governance.

cards.heading: Implement CI/CD
cards.body: Continuous integration and deployment pipelines ensure consistent, reliable delivery while reducing manual errors and deployment time.

cards.heading: Automate testing
cards.body: Automated testing validates that applications and infrastructure work correctly before deployment, reducing the risk of failures in production.

cards.heading: Automate deployments
cards.body: Automated deployments eliminate manual errors and provide predictable, repeatable processes for both applications and infrastructure.

cards.heading: Zero downtime deployments
cards.body: Zero-downtime deployment strategies aim to reduce or eliminate downtime when you update your infrastructure or applications.
